dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey clouds of an early morning sky.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, in a far off kingdom, there lay a small village at the edge of the woods... Suddenly, the WELL-WORN BOOT of Cinderella steps into the frame and lands on what we thought was the sky, but in fa is simply its reflection in a puddle of water. A strong C accents the splash and we begin a musical vamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on CINDERELLA'S dirty hand as it reaches down to gather kindling.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And in this village... CLOSE-UP on a bead of sweat as it trickles from her brow, same hand entering the frame to wipe it.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... lived a young maiden... ANGLE on CINDERELLA A pretty (and filthy) young woman, who finishes mopping h brow and trudges towards the back of a large house, the kindling under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... a care-free young lad...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A spaced-out twelve year-old who is trying to pull his bo cow MILKY-WHITE towards his dilapidated cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on a ball of dough. The BAKER'S thick hand pound it.

dialogues.text: ... and a childless baker...

dialogues.speaker: THE BAKER AND HIS WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S MOTHER, bedraggled, takes in the laundry.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The young lad had no father, and his MOTHER-- JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, she was at her wit's end-- JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S MOTHER enters the house and stops dead in her trac when she sees the cow. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in heaven's name are you doing with the cow inside the house? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought if he was nice and warm he might produce some milk. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a she! How many times must I tell you? Only shes can give milk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER and his WIFE are scurrying about the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then there was a hungry little girl who always wore a red cape... The BAKER turns to see a small hand rise up and snatch on the BUNS off the counter. 6  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! The BAKER swiftly comes around the counter where a small, plump young girl in a red cape, LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD studies the goodies. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STEPSISTERS are still laughing at CINDERELLA. The STEPMOTHER looks around the room and sees a large bowl of lentils. She walks over, picks it up and violently flings bowl towards CINDERELLA strewing the beans across the roo and into the fireplace. STEPMOTHER (CHEERY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinderella, if you can pick up these lentils, and finish your chores in time, then you may go to the ball with us. (to her DAUGHTERS) Come along, ladies... STEPSISTERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother. They sweep out of the room giggling. BACK ON CINDERELLA. She stands forlornly, studying the me that awaits her. She closes her eyes and begins to gently sway as if going into a trance. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is trying to milk the COW as his MOTHER looks on dubiously. JACK

dialogues.speaker: NO, SQUEEZE, PAL ...
dialogues.text: JACK'S MOTHER hears the loud squalling of birds and runs the window, sticking her head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds flying en masse over their house. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the BIRDS swarming and flying down the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA opens her eyes to greet the birds that now surround her. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE POT...
dialogues.text: The BIRDS spread out and begin their task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK sits atop MILKY-WHITE as if she were a horse, his ar WHIRLING as he releases a sling and sends a STONE hurtlin towards a TIN CUP on top of the door frame. There is a lo "CLANG". JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullseye! JACK'S MOTHER was just exiting the house. The CUP falls d narrowly missing her. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Stop your pretending! She grabs JACK'S sling and pulls him away from the COW.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now listen to me well, son. Milky-White must be taken to market. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, no-- he's the best cow in the WORLD-- JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was. She's been dry for weeks. We've no food or money and no choice but to sell her. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Milky-White is my best friend! JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her!

dialogues.speaker: HER RUMP/ BIG ENOUGH TO BE A HUMP
dialogues.text: JACK BUT-- 8  JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: ONE KEEPS A COW FOR A FRIEND
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder what's in that head of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH gives the BAKER a coin as his WIFE looks on adoringl She loves having the little girl here. The Baker, not so much. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: THE WOODS TO GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE...
dialogues.text: She shoves the entire bun into her mouth. LRRH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with her mouth full)

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE...
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're certain of your way? As LRRH sings, she begins to help herself to all the buns can lay her hands on. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: ARE JUST WOOD./
dialogues.text: (to the Wife)

dialogues.speaker: HAVE A BASKET
dialogues.text: The WIFE reaches for a basket, while the BAKER tries to w away a bun or two from the girl. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you're planning on buying any of these? The WIFE gives the BAKER a look, then hands LRRH a basket WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't stray and be late! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you might save some of those sweets for Granny. 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER, and his WIFE are in front of their shop, watch as LRRH skips down the lane. LRRH (TO HERSELF))

dialogues.speaker: KNOW, SHE'S ALREADY DEAD.
dialogues.text: Her path takes her through an ancient GRAVEYARD and on towards the forest's edge. LRRH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BIRDS are dropping the last of the lentils into the p

dialogues.speaker: LUCINDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Cinderella!

dialogues.speaker: FLORINDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Get up here! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: FLY BIRDS,/ BACK TO THE SKY,/
dialogues.text: The BIRDS begin to make their way out through the firepla and windows as CINDERELLA sings her incantation.

dialogues.speaker: LUCINDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We are waiting! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room of mirrors. LUCINDA and FLORINDA, dressed in their ball gowns, study themselves side by side, reflected over over. CINDERELLA enters through a mirrored door, breaking image. FLORINDA

dialogues.speaker: HURRY UP AND DO MY HAIR, CINDERELLA
dialogues.text: FLORINDA pulls at one of LUCINDA'S bows. FLORINDA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCINDA grabs CINDERELLA. LUCINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to her SLEEVE)

dialogues.speaker: CINDERELLA
dialogues.text: LUCINDA eyes FLORINDA'S hair. LUCINDA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CAN'T YOU HIDE IT WITH A HAT
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA grabs a stool and brings it next to FLORINDA. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: YOU LOOK BEAUTIFUL.
dialogues.text: She stands on the stool and begins fixing FLORINDA'S hair FLORINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. LUCINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She means me. FLORINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she didn't! The two STEPSISTERS bicker as CINDERELLA brushes and twis their hair into tight curls:

dialogues.speaker: CINDERELLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (INTERNAL)

dialogues.speaker: CINDERELLA,/ NICE GOOD GOOD NICE--
dialogues.text: FLORINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tighter! CINDERELLA obliges and becomes more aggressive with the h styling, her emotions building as she thinks to herself:

dialogues.speaker: CINDERELLA--/ NICE GOOD NICE KIND GOOD
dialogues.text: NICE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLORINDA screams, bringing CINDERELLA back to reality. FLORINDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Not that tight! Clod! She reels around and smacks CINDERELLA who stands stunned The STEPSISTERS giggle and snort. 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER and his WIFE are cleaning up after their day's work. There is an unexpected knock at the door. They star one another momentarily. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who might that be? WIFE (CALLING OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've sold our last loaf of bread! The BAKER opens the window a crack to see who is at the d BAKER (ALARMED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Witch from next door! The DOOR pops off its frame and goes flying across the ro in a giant puff of smoke. The BAKER and his WIFE scream a cower in a corner. As the fog clears, we see the WITCH for the first time an she's not a pretty sight. MICE and other vermin drop from beneath her cape and scatter through the cottage. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no bread. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your bread. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what is it you wish? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what I wish. It's what you wish. She moves towards the WIFE as the BAKER tries unsuccessfu to protect her. She points her gross finger towards her belly. WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing cooking in that belly now, is there? And there will never be... She looks away. WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you do exactly as I say. In three days' time, a Blue Moon will appear. Only then can the curse be undone. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What curse? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one I placed on this house! 12  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the past, when you were no more than a babe, your father brought his young wife and you to this cottage. They were a lovely couple. But not lovely neighbors. You see, your mother was with child and she developed an unusual appetite. She admired my beautiful garden and she told your father that what she wanted, more than anything in the world was--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITCH'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the moonlight, we see the BAKER'S FATHER, wearing a hunting jacket, scale over the WITCH'S wall and into her garden. From behind a wooden trellis, she WATCHES him as gathers her greens:

dialogues.speaker: ROOTING THROUGH MY RUTABAGA,/ RAIDING
dialogues.text: MY ARUGULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, only seeing the WITCH from behind, she confronts t BAKER'S FATHER as he sheepishly holds the stolen vegetabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITCH

dialogues.speaker: AND WE'LL CALL IT SQUARE."
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a brother? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But you had a sister. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's mine now and you'll never find her! Small price to pay for what else your father stole from me. It cost me my youth, my beauty. My mother warned me she would punish me with the curse of ugliness if I ever lost them. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost what? WITCH (IMPATIENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beans! BAKER/WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beans? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER'S FATHER steals the WITCH'S beans and pockets t

dialogues.speaker: STOLEN MY BEANS
dialogues.text: WITCH'S POV - the BAKER'S FATHER scales his way back over garden wall.

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTNING FLASH
dialogues.text: Lights suddenly illuminate the BAKER'S FATHER as if it wa flash from the Hiroshima blast. A look of horror crosses face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light illuminates the WITCH as she walks back towards her house. Suddenly her youthful hands morph before our eyes those of an aged hag. The CAMERA PANS UP to find her with face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIGHTNING FLASH rips through the Baker's cottage. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the WITCH'S gross hands snatch the baby from a cra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITCH

dialogues.speaker: WOULD ALWAYS BE/ A BARREN ONE...
dialogues.text: The WIFE falls into the BAKER'S arms, weeping. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do that to me? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when your mother died, your father deserted you. Your father was no father -- so why should you be? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his WIFE) I'm so sorry... WITCH

dialogues.speaker: I'M TELLING YOU THE SAME/ I TELL KINGS
dialogues.text: AND QUEENS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WITCH grabs some magical looking beans from a SMALL SATCHEL she carries across her body. She displays them. 15  WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK with his cow stands outside with his MOTHER. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I have to go to the next village? JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because everyone in this village knows the cow hasn't given a drop of milk in weeks. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's cheating. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're starving, Jack. Don't you understand that? You're not to take less than five pounds for her. Are you listening to me? JACK (HE'S NOT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are you to ask? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more than five pounds. She grabs his ear and squeezes it hard.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S MOTHER JACK
dialogues.text: Less! Than five. ... than five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets go and puts the COW'S leash in his hand and push him down the road towards the woods. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: TO JOURNEY'S END--
dialogues.text: JACK (STOPS; SADLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WITCH, the BAKER, the BAKER'S WIFE. 16  WITCH

dialogues.speaker: YOU WISH TO HAVE THE CURSE REVERSED
dialogues.text: The BAKER and his WIFE nod. WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: I'LL NEED A CERTAIN POTION FIRST.
dialogues.text: The WITCH intently turns on them. WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CHILD CAN BE.
dialogues.text: (SHE EXPLODES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the wood! The WITCH flings her arms and a hundred-mile wind throws couple and all of their belongings across the room as she disappears in a cloud of smoke -- or is it flour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open-air carriage and horses wait in the courtyard. Th STEPMOTHER, dressed to the nines, sweeps out of the house impatiently calls over her shoulder. STEPMOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies. Our carriage awaits! CINDERELLA darts out of the house holding out the bowl of lentils to her STEPMOTHER. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: NOW MAY I GO TO THE FESTIVAL
dialogues.text: STEPMOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Festival! DARLING, THOSE NAILS!/

dialogues.speaker: FESTIVAL/ AND MORTIFY THE PRINCE
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The festival lasts three nights. Surely you can let me be there for one of them. STEPMOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King is trying to find his son a wife -- not a scullery maid! We must be gone! 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the STEPMOTHER climbs into the carriage, the STEPSISTE race by in their fancy attire, whooshing past CINDERELLA excitedly. As CINDERELLA watches from the doorway, the carriage leav through the gate. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER is trying to clean up the mess when his WIFE ra downstairs holding his FATHER'S HUNTING JACKET. She hands to the BAKER. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take this... BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not wearing that. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my father's. You heard what she said. This is all his fault. The BAKER throws the jacket to the ground. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want nothing to do with him! The WIFE sees that BEANS have spilled out of the pocket. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! She picks them up. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beans. The Witch's beans! We'll take them with us. BAKER (REALIZING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? Wait a minute! You're not coming. It's not safe out there. The BAKER puts a hunting knife in his belt. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I can do this on my own. 18  BAKER WIFE

dialogues.speaker: ON OUR HOUSE.
dialogues.text: BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now tell me. What am I to return with? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember?!

dialogues.speaker: CORN,/ THE SLIPPER AS PURE AS GOLD.
dialogues.text: BAKER (MEMORIZING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As CINDERELLA approaches the gate, an old GROUNDSKEEPER closes and locks it. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the cottage behind him, the BAKER appears dressed fo his journey. His WIFE hurries towards him with his satche and places it around his neck. He proceeds down the cobblestone lane, his WIFE walking next to him. CINDERELLA looks through the bars, watching the CARRIAGE disappear down the road. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: CORN...
dialogues.text: WIFE CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting him) I KNOW -- I'LL VISIT MOTHER'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA has thrown a shawl around herself and is headi out the back of the house. She places a ladder against th stone wall and begins to climb. The BAKER and his WIFE le the village and begin moving towards the woods. CINDERELLA/BAKER

dialogues.speaker: TO TAKE THE JOURNEY.
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: YOU KNOW IT WELL,
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: BUT WHO CAN TELL--
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him a little PUSH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA climbs over the wall. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S MOTHER watches from the distance as JACK leads MIL WHITE up the path. JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him)

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE WOODS TO SELL THE COW--
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA drops down from the wall and runs off. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH enters an archway that frames the entrance into the woods. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING: THE BAKER entering the same archway; CINDER crossing a stream; and LRRH weaving her way down a gully.

dialogues.speaker: ARE JUST WOOD./ NO NEED TO BE AFRAID
dialogues.text: THERE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All THREE of them stop with sudden trepidation. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: THERE'S SOMETHING IN THE GLADE THERE.
dialogues.text: The BAKER walks deeper into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage carrying the STEPFAMILY crosses a small coun bridge, then passes JACK'S MOTHER. One of the wheels turn a puddle and splashes her with mud. ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK enters the archway into the woods with his COW. ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS ANGLES on each of our CHARACTERS in different woodland surrounds. STEPS

dialogues.speaker: TO SEE THE KING--
dialogues.text: JACK

dialogues.speaker: TO SELL THE COW--
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: TO MAKE THE POTION--
dialogues.text: QUICK INTERCUTS between the characters: ALL

dialogues.speaker: THE FESTIVAL--
dialogues.text: The CAMERA slowly rises through the trees as the vast for swallows up our intrepid travellers. 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large willow tree stands tall.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Deep within the woods, Cinderella had planted a branch at the grave of her mother. And she visited there so often, and wept so much, that her tears watered it until it had become a magnificent tree. CINDERELLA kneels in prayer. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: I WISH...
dialogues.text: She begins to cry. MUSIC. In the reflection, CINDERELLA sees the tree slowly twist turn taking on the shape of her MOTHER, who looks down up her. C'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it that you wish, child? CINDERELLA looks up to see her MOTHER in the tree.

dialogues.speaker: YOU SHALL HAVE YOUR WISH.
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA closes her eyes and makes her wish. ANOTHER ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind now blowing the willow tree, its LEAVES begin to rain down on CINDERELLA, turning gold and silver as they swirl around her, transforming her clothes into a beautif gown. CINDERELLA looks down to see that she is now wearing a pa of shoes literally made of gold leaf. When she looks back the tree has now returned to its former shape. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mother. She dashes into the woods. 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH walks along the path.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On her path to Granny's, the little girl suddenly found herself in a very unusual part of the wood. WOLF'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branches and leaves rush by in a blur. Suddenly, the CAME stops, and in the distance we see LRRH strolling down a p of exotic flowers as she munches on a treat. We hear HEAV BREATHING. The CAMERA continues stalking its prey, moving closer towards LRRH through the brush. ANGLE on LRRH, as she continues walking and eating.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Good day, young lady. She turns around and what she sees - through a CHILD'S EY is a super-slick, good-looking guy. What she doesn't noti is his curiously low hairline, something of a snout, and tail peeking from his waistcoat. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Mr. Wolf. WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whither away so hurriedly? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my Grandmother's. WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what might be in your basket? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bread for Grandmother so she'll have something good to make her strong. WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where might your Grandmother live? LRRH (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quarter of a league further in the woods; her house stands inside a great oak tree. She continues on the path. The WOLF looks after her longingly. 23  WOLF

dialogues.speaker: ONE'S ESPECIALLY LUSH,/ DELICIOUS...
dialogues.text: With inhuman speed, he manages to suddenly be back in fro of the girl on the path. WOLF (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: HOURS,/ TAKE YOUR TIME.
dialogues.text: LRRH

dialogues.speaker: TO DELAY/ OR BE MISLED.
dialogues.text: She continues moving forward, he slithers around her. Thi WOLF has some smooth moves. WOLF

dialogues.speaker: YOU'RE TRAVELLING SO FLEETLY.
dialogues.text: He drops behind again, thinking to himself. WOLF (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: UTTER PERFECTION
dialogues.text: SUPPLE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Racing ahead and then darting out from a tree. WOLF (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: ONE MOMENT, MY DEAR--
dialogues.text: LRRH

dialogues.speaker: THE PATH/ AND NEVER STRAY."
dialogues.text: WOLF

dialogues.speaker: YOU'RE IGNORING...
dialogues.text: He ushers LRRH off the path to a lush meadow blanketed wi exquisite purple flowers and wild berries. 24  WOLF (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working himself up)

dialogues.speaker: MEAL
dialogues.text: The WOLF picks a flower and hands it to LRRH. WOLF (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Granny. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: MIGHT LIKE/ A FRESH BOUQUET.../
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Wolf. WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, little girl./ AND HELLO... The WOLF climbs to the top of a precipice where he is silhouetted by the red hot sun. He lets out a mighty howl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH goes about her business picking flowers further from path. ANGLE ON THE BAKER who has been observing LRRH from a distance. Like a bat, the WITCH swings upside down from a tree above the BAKER: WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you standing there?! Go get the cape! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You frightened me! The WITCH swings to the ground. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it! Get it! Get it! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to get it? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go up to the little thing, and you take it. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't just take a cloak from a little girl. Why don't you take it! 25  WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the rules. Why do you think I asked you in the first place? I'm not allowed to touch any of the objects! We suddenly hear the lilting sound of a young voice singi in the distance. The WITCH, almost intoxicated by her sou swoons with delight. Then: WITCH (CONT'D) (YELLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me what I need! Get me what I need! She wraps the cape about herself and disappears in such a strong blast of wind that it knocks the BAKER to the grou BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous! ANOTHER ANGLE. LRRH is picking flowers off the path, blit unaware of anything else. The BAKER gets up and hurries o to her. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there little girl. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Baker. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you saved some of those sweets for Granny? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ate all the sweets and half the loaf of bread. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I see! Now tell me...where did you get that beautiful cape? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Granny made it for me. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? I would love a red cape like that. LRRH (GIGGLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd look pretty foolish. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I take a look at it? He quickly unties it. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls it off her back, she grabs the other side. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need it badly. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- give it back! They have a tug of war. The BAKER pulls free and runs off with the cape. LRRH sta there momentarily stunned, then lets out a loud scream. ANGLE ON THE BAKER. He stops cold, realizing what he's do then runs back to LRRH and places the cape around her shoulders. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just wanted to make sure that you really loved this cape. Now off you go to Granny's -- and be careful that no wolf comes your way. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would rather a wolf than you any day. LRRH stamps on his foot. The BAKER hops on his good foot. BAKER (DISTRAUGHT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is hopeless. I'll never get that red cape or find a golden cow and a yellow slipper -- or was it a golden slipper and a yellow cow?

dialogues.speaker: CORN,/ THE SLIPPER AS PURE AS--
dialogues.text: He stops in his tracks. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? The WIFE steps out from behind a thicket. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot your scarf. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be here. It's not safe in these woods! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to help. She goes to tie the WOOL SCARF around his neck but he pul away. 27  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! THE SPELL IS ON MY HOUSE-- WIFE OUR HOUSE-- BAKER WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two stop cold when they notice JACK and his COW comin down the path towards them. WIFE (CONT'D) (MURMURED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cow as white as ... They look at each other. BOTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... milk. The WIFE pushes the BAKER in JACK'S direction, then follo BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there, young lad. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What might you be doing with a cow in the middle of the forest? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was heading toward market -- but I seem to have lost my way. WIFE (COACHING BAKER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you planning to do there? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you planning to do there? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell my cow, sir. No less than five pounds. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five pounds! (TO WIFE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we to get five pounds? The WIFE moves forward to JACK as the BAKER goes through pockets of his hunting jacket looking for money. 28  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be generous of milk to fetch five pounds? JACK (HESITANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you can't fetch that sum? Then what are you to do? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadn't thought of that... BAKER (TO WIFE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all we have... She inspects his hand, which holds a few coins and the si magic beans. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, for the benefit of the boy) Beans? We mustn't give up our beans! Well, if you feel we must... BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beans in exchange for my cow? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, these are no ordinary beans, son. These beans carry...magic. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic? What kind of magic? WIFE (TO BAKER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him! The BAKER has no idea. He makes something up. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic that defies description. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many beans? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five! (TO JACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're worth a pound each, at least. 29  JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I buy my cow back someday? BAKER (UNEASY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... The WIFE gives him a little poke. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...possibly. Here. He hands JACK the five beans, carefully dropping them one a time into the boy's hand. The WIFE quickly takes the SI BEAN and puts it in her pocket. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck there, young lad. As the BAKER takes the cow's leash, JACK wraps his arms around the bony animal. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day, I'll buy you back -- Promise! JACK kisses the cow. The BAKER looks to his WIFE guiltily Overcome with emotion, JACK runs back into the woods. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the cow and go home! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to help. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic beans! We've no reason to believe they're magic! Are we going to dispel this curse through deceit? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one would have given him more for this creature. We did him a favor. At least they'll have some food. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five beans?! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we want a child or not? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. But... WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have one chance. Don't you see that? And if we fail... 30  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not sure I'm cut out to be a father. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of my father. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not him. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't do this for yourself, can't you at least do it for me? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. You take the cow and go home. I'll find the rest of the things. On my own. The BAKER walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAPUNZEL'S PRINCE glides through the woods on a white ste It's difficult to say who is more beautiful, the PRINCE o the HORSE. From the corner of his eye he notices somethin the distance. He slows down and circles back, and HEARS t melodious singing of RAPUNZEL. He dismounts and slips thr the brush to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R-PRINCE POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exquisite tower, surrounded by a thicket of tall rose bushes, with no entryway, just a lone window at its peak. the bottom of the tower, the WITCH looks upward: WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapunzel. Rapunzel. Let down your hair to me. The PRINCE, hiding within the brush. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savoring the name) Rapunzel... At the window, the gorgeous young blonde girl, RAPUNZEL proceeds to lower the longest stretch of hair you've ever seen. The WITCH scales up the tower. (This causes more th little discomfort for RAPUNZEL.) 31

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The old enchantress had given the name Rapunzel to the child she had hidden away and locked in a a doorless tower. But little did she know that the girl's lilting voice had caught the attention of a handsome Prince." R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapunzel... The PRINCE dashes back to his horse and gallops off. The WITCH arrives at the window. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you look lovely today, my dear. RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mother. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought your favorite. Blackberries, fresh from the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH walks over a rickety bridge that spans a brook. She stops and stares at the cottage which is built into a lar OAK TREE.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As the little girl approached her Granny's oak tree, she was surprised to see the door standing open. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, how uneasy I feel. Perhaps it's all the sweets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH makes her way down a curved staircase in the house. sees the CURTAINS drawn around her GRANNY'S BED and, behi them, the SILHOUETTE of what "looks like" GRANNY. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny? WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a granny voice) Come in, my deary. LRRH moves towards the bed with trepidation and slowly pu back the curtain. The WOLF is revealed, lying under the covers, dressed in GRANNY'S nightcap and robe. 32  LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, Grandmother. You're looking very strange. What big ears you have! WOLF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The better to hear you with, my dear. The handsome WOLF flashes a smile that reveals a set of gleaming white FANGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER crosses the bridge and heads towards the cottag He suddenly hears LRRH scream. Nervously he pulls the kni from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And with a single bound, the wolf had devoured the little girl. Well, it was a full day of eating for both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER enters and hears a loud SNORE. Brandishing the knife, he moves towards the bed where he sees the WOLF DRESSED AS GRANNY, sound asleep, a piece of the red cloth sticking out of it's mouth. Squeamishly, he pulls back the sheet to see the WOLF'S SWOLLEN STOMACH. He raises his knife and as he brings it slashing down we hear a loud HOWL from the WOLF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP ON THE BAKER, clearly shaken, leaving the cottage walking away. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I just did that. LRRH and GRANNY appear at the doorway behind him. LRRH (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! GRANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to help us skin that beast? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks! GRANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of hunter are you? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a baker. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANNY gives him a disdainful look and goes back into the house. LRRH in her cape runs after the BAKER as he approa the rickety bridge. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I never thanked you. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to be more careful, young lady. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I should have known better.

dialogues.speaker: EXCITED AND SCARED.
dialogues.text: LRRH relives her nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH walks down the staircase towards GRANNY'S bed. She s the WOLF'S silhouette through the bed curtains.

dialogues.speaker: WELL, EXCITED AND SCARED./
dialogues.text: LRRH grabs hold of the bed curtains and pulls them around herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LRRH falls down a dark cavernous void.

dialogues.speaker: KNOW,/
dialogues.text: She lands and sees a blurry form in the distance before realizing it is GRANNY.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATH/ WAS GRANNY ONCE AGAIN.
Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANNY reaches out her arms blindly until the two are uni in a warm embrace.

dialogues.speaker: AND SET US FREE,
dialogues.text: LRRH POV -- A crack of light widens until it's clear that is seeing a KNIFE opening the WOLF'S STOMACH that creates blinding light. The BAKER'S EYE peeks through the slit.

dialogues.speaker: AND YOU BROUGHT US TO THE LIGHT,
dialogues.text: LRRH reaches for the BAKER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the BAKER takes her hand. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: AND WE'RE BACK AT THE START.
dialogues.text: She continues her story. LRRH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: HOOD,
dialogues.text: She takes off her cape. LRRH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: GOOD.
dialogues.text: Mr. Baker. You saved our lives. Here. LRRH hands him the cape. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you certain? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Maybe Granny will make me another with the skins of the wolf. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you! Impulsively he gives her a kiss on the cheek and as he leaves, the girl wipes it off. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuck! 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes her way back to GRANNY'S. LRRH (CONT'D) (TO HERSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having just greeted JACK on his return, his MOTHER stares the beans he has just handed her. JACK'S MOTHER (DESPAIRING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do this? What sort of boy would exchange a cow for beans? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're magic -- the man said -- JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your head out of the clouds! She angrily THROWS the beans to the ground. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother -- no! She turns to grab JACK'S ear, failing to see the electric sparks that flare when the beans strike the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragging him up to the hayloft and pushing him on to his JACK'S MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your worthless adventures! Will you never learn, Jack?! To bed without supper for you! She storms away. JACK lies on his bed bereft. He sees his sling on the floor and picks it up cradling it as he clos his eyes. THE CAMERA travels to a hole in the wall and looks below see five bean stalks already growing and intertwining, quickly reaching skyward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT. Sitting on a hilltop surrounded by the woods o all sides, a magical and ageless castle sits aglow. A hug FULL MOON hangs in the sky, but there's already the slith of a SHADOW beginning to cross its face. We hear MUSIC in the background along with the jovial sou of the ball. 36

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The first night of the festival ball brought Cinderella her wish. The Prince danced only with her, `til he turned and she had slipped away. Suddenly CINDERELLA in her ball-gown rushes out of a back entrance and onto the terrace disappearing around a corne

dialogues.speaker: THE STEPS
dialogues.text: She descends a long stretch of ancient stone steps that l to the outside grounds.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: She appears running down a garden path below and into the woods. A beat later, CINDERELLA'S PRINCE, dashes out on t drawbridge where he spots CINDERELLA below. He is tall, d and impossibly handsome. His STEWARD and other attendants join him. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must find that girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER'S WIFE is trying to find her way back to the village, pulling an obstinate MILKY-WHITE on a leash behi her. We see a piece of the castle in the distance. We TRACK CINDERELLA racing through the brush -- not an ea feat in a ball gown and gold slippers. We hear VOICES in distance and the NEIGHING OF HORSES. CINDERELLA stumbles knoll, loses her footing and rolls over and over to the bottom landing with a spectacular THUD just yards from th WIFE. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, miss? CINDERELLA (STARTLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I just need to catch my breath. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful gown you're wearing. Were you at the King's Festival? CINDERELLA, preoccupied, collects herself so she can cont on her way. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you the lucky one. Why ever are you in the woods at this hour? We hear the PRINCE'S ENTOURAGE approaching. 37

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This way! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Don't let them know I'm here. She quickly hides herself in the brush. The WIFE turns ar and looks to the top of the rise to see C-PRINCE on a bla stallion, with his STEWARD and ATTENDANTS in tow. He call down to the WIFE. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen a beautiful young woman in a ball gown pass through? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Breathless as she BOWS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, sir. STEWARD (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may, my lord, I think I see her over there. The ENTOURAGE races off and CINDERELLA reappears and sits catching her breath. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never lied to royalty before. I've never anything to royalty before! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a prince were looking for me, I certainly wouldn't hide. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what brings you here -- and with a cow? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my husband's somewhere in the woods. (WITH PRIDE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's undoing a spell. CINDERELLA (IMPRESSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. But tell me, the Prince, what was he like? CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: HE'S A VERY NICE PRINCE.
dialogues.text: 38  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: AND--/ IT'S A VERY NICE BALL.
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: AND--/ WHEN I ENTERED, THEY TRUMPETED.
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: AND--
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: OH, THE PRINCE...
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: YES, THE PRINCE
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: WELL, HE'S TALL.
dialogues.text: The WIFE sits down next to CINDERELLA admiring her dress they chat. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: CHARMING.
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: WE DID NOTHING BUT DANCE.
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: YES--
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: AND IT MADE A NICE CHANGE.
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: NO, THE PRINCE
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: OH, THE PRINCE...
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: YES, THE PRINCE.
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: HE HAS CHARM FOR A PRINCE, I GUESS...
dialogues.text: WIFE

dialogues.speaker: GUESS
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: AND IT'S ALL VERY STRANGE.
dialogues.text: 39  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would you run away? CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not quite what I expected. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princes, castles, gowns... CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no experience with those things. We hear the far off CHIMES OF MIDNIGHT from the castle. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you will return to the Festival tomorrow eve? CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... No... I don't know... WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know? What I wouldn't give to be in your shoes. (looking to her SHOES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I mean your slippers. (EXCITED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As pure as gold? CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must get home. CINDERELLA runs off. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! I need your shoes! The WIFE goes after CINDERELLA but then hears a distant C MOAN. She turns around to discover that MILKY-WHITE has t off. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky-White! The WITCH appears from nowhere. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One midnight gone! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already?! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that cow! The WIFE takes off after the cow as the CAMERA RISES abov tree level. The BLUE SHADOW has moved a little further ac the face of the MOON. 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STRAGGLY ROOSTER crowing, the sun cutting across its pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK'S MOTHER is woken by the rooster crow to find someth ticking her nose. She opens her eyes, brushing the "something" away -- then sees that it's a huge LEAF pushing in through an open sla the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cottage, now dwarfed by a giant BEANSTALK. JACK'S MOT a tiny figure from this distance, comes running out of th house, takes one look at the giant plant and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various angles of JACK, running feverishly through the wo in search of the BAKER. He carries a huge sack of LARGE-S COINS over his back. He occasionally calls out: "Mr. Bake The BAKER, peacefully asleep is curled up in a large root clutching the red cape like it was his blankie. Suddenly leaps from atop calling his name and waking him. JACK (SHOUTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baker! Mr. Baker! BAKER (HALF ASLEEP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good fortune! Good fortune, sir! Look what I have! Five gold pieces. BAKER (SKEPTICAL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you come by five gold pieces?! JACK

dialogues.speaker: SKY
dialogues.text: JACK throws him the bag and begins to scale up the root o the tree. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: HOW SMALL YOU ARE.
dialogues.text: (MORE) 41  JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is now climbing the BEANSTALK.

dialogues.speaker: DARE/ 'CAUSE YOU DON'T CARE,/ WHEN
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY THERE'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK is half-way up the tree with the BAKER below. JACK

dialogues.speaker: A BIG TALL TERRIBLE GIANT AT THE DOOR.
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK (in the tree). JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: KNEW BEFORE,/ NOT TILL THE SKY.
dialogues.text: The BAKER listens intently. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK scurries down the BEANSTALK, with the large SACK OF COINS over his shoulder, occasionally looking up to see i is being followed.

dialogues.speaker: CAN AND RUN
dialogues.text: (MORE) 42

dialogues.speaker: BELOW,/ AND THE WORLD YOU KNOW/ BEGINS
dialogues.text: TO GROW:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK looks down to the BAKER. JACK

dialogues.speaker: YOU COULD LIVE IN BETWEEN,/
dialogues.text: JACK now scurries down the tree. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: WONDERFUL GIANTS IN THE SKY
dialogues.text: JACK jumps from the tree and lands in front of the BAKER. up-ends the sack and dumps the five gold coins on the gro JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, here's your money, sir! Five gold pieces. Where is my Milky-White? BAKER (HESITANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky-White is back home with my wife. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go find them! JACK grabs the BAKER and excitedly tries to pull him alon BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! I'm not sure I want to sell. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said I could buy her back. Do you want more money? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! It's not that-- JACK (IGNORING HIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep that. I'll fetch some more. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I didn't say-- But JACK doesn't wait to listen. Taking the EMPTY SACK, h runs off excitedly. 43  BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER follows after JACK and collides into his WIFE, dropping his satchel and revealing the red cape. He hides money sack. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... She doesn't want to tell him she's lost MILKY-WHITE. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you've got the red cape! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I've got the cape. Only two items left. WIFE (SHEEPISH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. We've the cape and the cow. WIFE (FAKED ENTHUSIASM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've the cape... BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done with the cow?! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ran away. I never reached home. I've been looking for her all night. BAKER (ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might just as easily have run from you! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she didn't! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: BUT SHE MIGHT HAVE
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WITCH appears in the tree directly above them. WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: BACK
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just going to do that. Here. He climbs towards her with the cape. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have this-- WITCH

dialogues.speaker: DON'T COME NEAR ME WITH THAT, FOOL
dialogues.text: can't touch it! By midnight tomorrow bring me the items or that child you wish for will never see the light of day! With a grand sweep of her cape, the WITCH throws off dirt muck over the BAKER and the BAKER'S WIFE as she disappear into a cloud of dust. The BAKER wipes dirt from his mouth. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like that woman. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I lost the cow. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have yelled. (firmly but kindly) Go back to the village. I will make things right. And then we can just go about our life. No more witches or dim- witted boys or hungry little girls. The BAKER'S WIFE starts to speak. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!, please -- go. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT. We hear the hoofbeats of horses coming from bo directions. Crossing the frame and each other are CINDERELLA'S PRINCE on his BLACK stallion and RAPUNZEL'S PRINCE on his WHITE steed. They pass out of the frame. Af a few beats, they return trotting, meeting in the middle. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good brother. I was wondering where you'd gone. 45  C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been looking all night for her. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her? C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beautiful one I danced the evening with. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she go? C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappeared, like the fine morning mist. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was lovely? C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loveliest. They dismount and walk their horses through the forest. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not certain of that! I must confess, I too have found a lovely maiden. She lives here in the woods. C'S PRINCE (INCREDULOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woods? In the background we see the WIFE, who has wandered by on way back home. She stops to EAVESDROP on the PRINCES. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! In the top of a tall tower that has no door or stairs. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two leagues from here, due east, just beyond the mossy knoll near the rose thickets. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you manage a visit? R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand beneath her tower and say, "Rapunzel, Rapunzel, let down your hair to me." And then she lowers the longest, most beautiful head of hair - yellow as corn - which I climb. The WIFE is thrilled by this news, and runs off. 46  C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapunzel, Rapunzel! What kind of name is that? You jest! I have never heard of such a thing. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak the truth! She is as true as your maiden. A maiden running from a prince? None would run from us. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet one has. The PRINCES lead their horses to a stream that cascades i a magnificent waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: ONLY THING OUT OF YOUR REACH.
dialogues.text: R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: A LIGHTHEARTED AIR
dialogues.text: AHAH--"

dialogues.speaker: WITH YOU,/ IF THERE ONLY WERE DOORS.
dialogues.text: BOTH

dialogues.speaker: AGONY
dialogues.text: R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: WHAT'S AS INTRIGUING--
dialogues.text: C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: OR HALF SO FATIGUING--
dialogues.text: BOTH

dialogues.speaker: AS WHAT'S OUT OF REACH
dialogues.text: C-PRINCE studies his reflection in the water. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: AND HEIR TO A THRONE
dialogues.text: R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: FOR
dialogues.text: C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: THEN WHY NO--
dialogues.text: 47  R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: DO I KNOW
dialogues.text: C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL MUST BE MAD.
dialogues.text: The R-PRINCE scales a hanging vine as if it were RAPUNZEL hair. R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE WHILE HEARING HER,/ "AH-AH-AH-
dialogues.text: AH-AH-AH-AH-AH-AH-AH--" BOTH

dialogues.speaker: AGONY
dialogues.text: C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: MISERY
dialogues.text: R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: WOE
dialogues.text: BOTH

dialogues.speaker: THOUGH IT'S DIFFERENT FOR EACH.
dialogues.text: C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: ALWAYS TEN STEPS BEHIND--
dialogues.text: R'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: ALWAYS TEN FEET BELOW--
dialogues.text: BOTH

dialogues.speaker: I MUST HAVE HER TO WIFE.
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal the PRINCES side by side on a precipi overlooking the distant castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER'S WIFE fights her way through a thicket. Her clothes are now ratty, her face scratched - but she approaches the tower with trepidation. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rapunzel, Rapunzel? Let your hair down to me. The window at the top of the tower opens and RAPUNZEL sti out her head looking downward. The WIFE hides to the side RAPUNZEL (DUBIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that you at this hour, my Prince? 48  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in her best princely BASS VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. RAPUNZEL thinks about it for a moment, then lowers her ha The WIFE approaches it gingerly. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for this. She takes a fist full of hair and gives it a pull. Nothin She tries once again, this time with more force eliciting little yelp from RAPUNZEL. Finally, she holds on to the h and just starts running away from the tower as fast as sh can. We hear RAPUNZEL yell as the WIFE succeeds in pullin some of the hair from her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinderella flees the castle.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As the Baker's Wife bolted from the tower, the second night of the festival was thrown into chaos when Cinderella once again ran from the Prince. While the BAKER'S WIFE continues to run away from Rapunze tower, in the distance she sees a flutter of gold moving through the moonlit trees. CINDERELLA? She changes course pursuit. SERIES OF SHOTS with MUSIC CLOSE-UP on CINDERELLA'S SHOES as they make their way thr wooded path. ANGLE ON THE WIFE as she races towards them in pursuit. The WIFE catches up with CINDERELLA and tackles her to th ground, CINDERELLA'S slipper falling off. They both dive the slipper, when an approaching noise catches the WIFE'S attention.

dialogues.speaker: C'S PRINCE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Over here! CLOSE-UP on the shoe as CINDERELLA snatches it from the ground. CINDERELLA rushes off. The WIFE stares frozen in horror as the PRINCE'S HORSE ra towards her. She lets out a scream and the horse stops sh rearing up. The STEWARD'S horse charges off the path into thickets.

dialogues.speaker: C'S PRINCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is she? Where did she go? 49  WIFE (BOWING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea, sir. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play the fool, woman! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to hold her here for you... C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can capture my own damsel, thank you. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. The STEWARD returns, covered in burrs and looking none to happy. STEWARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of her, my liege. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what are you waiting for? See if you can find her. The STEWARD rides off. The PRINCE pauses. The ultimate seducer, he gives the WIFE the once over.

dialogues.speaker: C'S PRINCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The woods can be a dangerous place... She nods to him, out of her depth. He gallops off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER searches for MILKY-WHITE along a large PATHWAY, disheveled and exhausted. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moo... Moo...... He HEARS sounds off in the distance. BAKER'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STEPFAMILY'S carriage is passing through a large holl opening in the base of a huge tree. We can hear the STEPSISTERS bickering, their blonde hair bobbing animatedly. ANOTHER ANGLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAKER stands in the middle of the pathway, flagging d the carriage. He pulls an ear of corn from his satchel. A the carriage slows, he hops on the sideboard. 50  BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, if you would be so kind, may I compare this ear of corn with your hair? The STEPSISTERS scream.

dialogues.speaker: LUCINDA AND FLORINDA
dialogues.text: (OVERLAPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch us! Get away! How dare you! STEPMOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mongrel! (to the driver) Carry on! She pushes the BAKER off the carriage and he somersaults backwards into the brush. The CARRIAGE speeds off. Deflated, the BAKER picks himsel off the path and sits on what he thinks is a white rock. There is a muffled "Moo..." He jumps up realizing he's be SITTING on the cow. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky-White! He hears something and hides behind a BUSH. Then, seeing is his WIFE, he steps out. BAKER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were returning home! The WIFE screams in fright. Then she recognizes him. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! It's you! And you've the cow! She runs to MILKY-WHITE. BAKER (BRAGGADOCIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I've the cow. We've two of the four. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three! She shows him the braid of hair around her neck. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compare this to your corn. He does and it's a perfect match. 51  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find it? WIFE (FALSE MODESTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pulled it from a maiden in a tower. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I almost had the fourth, but she got away. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've one entire day left. Surely we can locate the slipper by then. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? You mean you're going to let me stay with you? BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...perhaps it will take the two of us to have this child. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: HEARTED/ THEN I KNEW/ YOU TO BE.
dialogues.text: BAKER

dialogues.speaker: YOU DO
dialogues.text: He flirts with her. She pulls away, teasing him. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: PASSIONATE, CHARMING, CONSIDERATE,
dialogues.text: CLEVER-- 52  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: ACCEPTING A SHARE/ OF WHAT'S THERE.
dialogues.text: They move towards each other through the trees playfully. BOTH

dialogues.speaker: MORE AND WE'RE DONE./
dialogues.text: They sit down next to each other at the top of a small hi and slide down to the bottom together. BOTH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: THREE./ WE NEED ONE./ IT TAKES TWO.
dialogues.text: They kiss but their moment of romance is interrupted when large GOLDEN EGG rolls down the hill between them. The WI screams.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop my egg! The BAKER stops the egg and picks it up. JACK stumbles do the hill. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, brilliant! My Milky-White. And the owners. And my egg! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Giant's hen! The BAKER'S WIFE examines the egg. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A golden egg! I've never seen a golden egg. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can have it. Along with the five gold pieces. 53  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five gold pieces? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm taking my cow. JACK moves to MILKY-WHITE. The distant CHIMES OF MIDNIGHT begin to ring out from the castle. BAKER JACK (OVERLAPPING) (OVERLAPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I never said I would But you took the five gold sell. pieces.  WIFE BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took five gold pieces?! I didn't take, you gave.  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the five gold pieces? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I could have my cow! BAKER WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I never said you could. I You would take money before said you might. child?!  BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no - it's not how it sounds! JACK (ALARMED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky-White...! MILKY-WHITE has begun to shake like a dashboard ornament. moans, then topples over with a loud thud. Alarmed, JACK to the cow and lays his head on the animal's chest. JACK (CONT'D) (TEARFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milky-White is dead! The BAKER looks up and sees that the SHADOW has now moved third of the way across the MOON. We hear the WITCH screa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hidden by a broken piece of WALL -- someone or something watching the R-PRINCE climbing out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When dawn broke, the Baker and his Wife had but one day left to reverse the Witch's curse. As for Rapunzel's Prince, he returned yet again to the forbidden tower. 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With RAPUNZEL smiling down, the R-PRINCE descends her hai Once he has reached the bottom, she pulls her hair back i and closes the window. ANOTHER ANGLE. We discover that it's the WITCH who has be watching. She is not happy. The PRINCE mounts his horse and rides off towards a low r thicket -- an easy jump. With a thrust of her stick, the WITCH makes the thicket s up before the PRINCE has time to act. His HORSE stops sho and he screams as he is thrown over the horse's head into thicket. ANGLE ON THE WITCH. She smiles at her handiwork then turn stare at the top of the tower vindictively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WITCH threatens RAPUNZEL. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: LISTEN.
dialogues.text: RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, please! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: WHAT WERE YOU NOT TO DO
dialogues.text: MUST SEE-- RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: EMBARRASS YOU.
dialogues.text: RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: YOU ARE ASHAMED OF ME.
dialogues.text: RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSTAND.
dialogues.text: 55  RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no longer a child. I wish to see the world. WITCH

dialogues.speaker: CHILD./ WITH ME.
dialogues.text: WITCH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you protection and yet you disobeyed me. RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your prince will never lay eyes on you again. He will never lay eyes on anything again! RAPUNZEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do to him? WITCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter because where you're going, no one will ever see you again. The WITCH lunges at RAPUNZEL with a pair of SHEARS and be to hack off her hair. The girl lets out a mighty shriek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK makes his way despondently through the oaks with his GOLDEN EGG. He comes across what looks like a WOLF, hunched over on t edge of the brush. He stops... then slowly approaches. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there - nice cape! The figure twists around, pulling a knife. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from my cape or I'll slash you into a thousand bits! 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure is revealed to be LRRH, in a wolf-skin cape, picking mushrooms for her granny. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! I don't want it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get it? LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Granny made it for me from a wolf that attacked us. And she gave me this beautiful knife for protection. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look what I have! A golden egg. He shows her his GOLDEN EGG. LRRH (SUSPICIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that egg? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the sky) I stole a hen that lays golden eggs from the kingdom of the Giant. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. And you should see the Giant's toy harp. It plays the most beautiful tunes without your even having to touch it. LRRH (SMIRKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it does. Why don't you go up to the kingdom right now and bring it back and show me? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could. LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could not! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could! LRRH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could not, Mr. Liar! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a liar! I'll get that harp. You'll see! He runs off. 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BEANSTALK & JACK'S FARMHOUSE - AFTERNOON To frantic MUSIC, JACK is making his way down to the bott of the beanstalk with all the speed he can muster. This i made more difficult by the GOLDEN HARP which he has slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jack took the little girl's dare and before he knew it, found himself fleeing from a Giant. Suddenly, the BEANSTALK shakes mightily, making JACK hold for dear life. He looks up to discover the Giant climbing down after him; Jack feverishly picks up speed and jumps last six feet to the ground. He quickly drops the harp an runs to a large axe embedded in the stump of a tree. JACK swings the AXE striking the BEANSTALK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SWING of the AXE is picked up by the BAKER snapping a branch that's in his way. The BAKER and his WIFE trudging through the woods. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've only one day left! I don't know where to start. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can start by buying a new cow with the money you took from the boy. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, where do I buy a cow? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to the next village, you'll find a cow there. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get the slipper. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yellow slipper?  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GOLDEN slipper! BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The golden slipper, that's what I meant. How are you going to get it? 58  WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have met a maiden with golden slippers these two previous nights. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could get one? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure of it. I'll meet you back here. BAKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we always separating? WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we have to if we're going to be together... The BAKER and his WIFE start to go off in opposite direct when there is a TREMENDOUS CRASH with the force of an earthquake. The BAKER and his WIFE are knocked off their and tumble into a bank of FERNS. They scramble to their f and look to one another. WIFE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Giant lies still on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The entire kingdom shook when the beanstalk came crashing down, killing the Giant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOON is now half covered by SHADOW. DROP DOWN to find CINDERELLA running down the steps; commotion ensues as sh followed by the PRINCE and his retinue.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...as for Cinderella, she fled from the Prince... again. ANOTHER ANGLE. Suddenly, when CINDERELLA is MID-FLIGHT on steps, she falters, unable to move. She looks down to see that there is TAR on this step and her shoes are stuck. ANGLE ON THE PRINCE. Smiling as he sees he has finally trapped his prey. We FREEZE the action as CINDERELLA considers the situatio 59  CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: THOUGHT,/ WHAT WOULD BE HIS RESPONSE
dialogues.text: She turns around to see the PRINCE, frozen in time and staring at her. CINDERELLA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: SHOES.
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA lifts her feet out of the shoes and moves to a step with no tar. She pulls one shoe from the tar, and as goes to pry the second shoe, she stops. CINDERELLA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE'LL DO.
dialogues.text: (MORE) 60  CINDERELLA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: STEPS OF THE PALACE
dialogues.text: Coming out of the freeze, she quickly leaves one shoe and slips on the other, then dashes off out of sight. The PRINCE picks up the golden shoe from the tar and hold up triumphantly. He addresses his STEWARD and RETINUE. C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball is over. Send everyone home. STEWARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Princess? C'S PRINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't get far with one shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on CINDERELLA'S FEET, awkwardly running with one shoe on, one shoe off. ANOTHER ANGLE. She hears someone close on her trail and l back to see the wide-eyed WIFE in pursuit. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come any closer to me! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, stop! Just hear me out! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have attacked me once before. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't attack you. I attacked your shoe. I need it. I have a magic bean in exchange for it. Breathless, CINDERELLA stops. Stands defensively. The WIF pulls out the bean from her pocket and hands it to her. CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic bean? Nonsense! CINDERELLA tosses it over her shoulder, but they don't se the SPARKS it sets off when it hits the ground and sinks the earth. She starts to leave. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, please. I haven't much time! (DESPERATE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need that shoe to have a child. 61  CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes no sense! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it make sense that you're running from a prince? The STEWARD approaches on HORSEBACK.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop! You there, stop! CINDERELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go! WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to take off a SHOE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my shoes. You'll run faster. CINDERELLA HERE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDERELLA hands the WIFE her GOLDEN SLIPPER. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! Thank you! CINDERELLA dashes off. ON THE WIFE AND STEWARD. STEWARD (SUSPICIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! What is that you have in your hand? The WIFE hides the slipper behind her back. The STEWARD dismounts. WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine. STEWARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
